For the general notations and definitions, please refer to Table I. Consider a distributed learning system involving a set of N𝑁N nodes (clients) 𝒩={1,2,…,N}𝒩12…𝑁\mathcal{N}=\{1,2,\ldots,N\}.
Let 𝒟n={(𝐱,y)}subscript𝒟𝑛𝐱𝑦\mathcal{D}_{n}=\{(\mathbf{x},y)\} be the local dataset associated with a node n∈𝒩𝑛𝒩n\in\mathcal{N} such that 𝐱∈𝒳⊂ℝd𝐱𝒳superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x}\in\mathcal{X}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}, y∈𝒴⊂ℝ𝑦𝒴ℝy\in\mathcal{Y}\subset\mathbb{R}, and Dn=|𝒟n|subscript𝐷𝑛subscript𝒟𝑛D_{n}=|\mathcal{D}_{n}|.
In the standard FL setting, given a subset of K<N𝐾𝑁K<N nodes 𝒩c⊂𝒩subscript𝒩𝑐𝒩\mathcal{N}_{c}\subset\mathcal{N}, the local loss is given by:

S6.T2.caption: Table II: Configuration Table
S6.T2.table:
Datasets Fashion-MNIST CIFAR10 CIFAR100
DNN/CNN Model LeNet-5 AlexNet ResNet-18
Number of pruning layers (Z𝑍Z) 5 8 18
Initial learning rate (η0subscript𝜂0\eta_{0}) 0.010.010.01 0.10.10.1 0.10.10.1
Number of clients per round (K𝐾K) 555 (out of 505050) 555 (out of 505050) 555 (out of 505050)
Batchsize in SGD 646464 128128128 128128128
Initial sparsity (s0subscript𝑠0s_{0}) 0.50.50.5 0.50.50.5 0.050.050.05
Global rounds (T𝑇T) 1,00010001,000 1,00010001,000 1,00010001,000
Reconfiguration interval (R𝑅R) 555 555 555
Regularization step size (Q𝑄Q) 101010 101010 101010
Local round (Elsubscript𝐸𝑙E_{l}) 555 555 555
Maximum penalty (λmaxsubscript𝜆\lambda_{\max}) 10−3superscript10310^{-3} 10−3superscript10310^{-3} 5⋅10−3⋅5superscript1035\cdot 10^{-3}
references:
Configurations: Table II details our configurations. For PruneFL, FedDST, and PruneTrain, we experimentally determined the optimal reconfiguration intervals R𝑅R to be 202020, 202020, and 111, respectively, to ensure the best possible model performance; the same for step size Q𝑄Q for all models. Especially, the annealing factor for FedDST is set as 0.50.50.5.
As SNIP prunes the model before training, the global mask is pruned via one-shot achieving the target sparsity spsubscript𝑠𝑝s_{p}. We used grid-search to fix the penalty factor for PruneTrain ranging from 10−1superscript10110^{-1} to 10−5superscript10510^{-5} for different experiments. When necessary, other hyperparameters were set to match ours. In non-i.i.d. case, the penalty for the proximal term in FedProx is determined via grid-search ranging from 10−1superscript10110^{-1} to 10−5superscript10510^{-5}. FedDIP+Prox adopts the optimal combination of penalty values for FedDIP and FedProx.

S6.T3.caption: Table III: Test Accuracy (top-1)
S6.T3.table:
Model Performance (%percent\%)1 with target sparsity spsubscript𝑠𝑝s_{p}
Model LeNet;sp=.9subscript𝑠𝑝.9s_{p}=.9 AlexNet;sp=.9subscript𝑠𝑝.9s_{p}=.9 ResNet;sp=.8subscript𝑠𝑝.8s_{p}=.8
FedAvg 89.50 (.09) 85.07 (.13) 70.92 (.10)
FedDP 88.06 (.08) 84.81 (.18) 69.23 (.14)
FedDIP 88.26 (0.09) 85.14 (.22) 69.67 (.10)
PruneFL 86.00 (.10) 81.64 (.17) 68.17 (.20)
SNIP 86.08 (.15) 80.10 (.15) 51.46 (.11)
PruneTrain 84.36 (.10) 79.73 (.10) 69.39 (.08)
FedDST 80.37 (.20) – 68.06 (.20)
# param.(FedAvg) 62K 23.3M 11.2M
# param.(pruned) 6.1K 2.3M 2.2M
1 Mean accuracy; standard deviation in ‘()’.
references:
Figures 2(a), 3(a), and 4(a) demonstrate that FedDIP surpasses other baselines in achieving the highest top-1 accuracy (ratio of the correctly classified images) while maintaining the same extreme target sparsity.
As indicated in Table III, to attain target sparsity of sp=0.9subscript𝑠𝑝0.9s_{p}=0.9 and sp=0.8subscript𝑠𝑝0.8s_{p}=0.8 respectively, FedDIP only compromises LeNet-5 and ResNet-18 model accuracy by 1.24%percent1.241.24\% and 1.25%percent1.251.25\%, respectively.
For AlexNet, FedDIP can even improve model performance 0.7%percent0.70.7\%, compared with FedAvg with sp=0.9subscript𝑠𝑝0.9s_{p}=0.9.

To make a fair comparison of cumulative communication cost during training (amount of information exchanged in MB)
w.r.t. a fixed budget, we showcase the relationship between communication cost and accuracy.
Figures 2(b), 3(b), 4(b), and specifically
Table IV present a comprehensive overview, emphasizing that FedDIP, when provided with adequate communication cost (budget),
effectively prunes the model across all experiments outperforming the other models. This indicates the trade-off between model performance and communication/training cost.
FedDIP demonstrates comparable communication efficiency to other baselines, principally due to the minimal decrement in model performance. Through our experiments, it is evidenced that FedDIP achieves optimally pruned models under
conditions of extreme sparsity, while incurring less or equivalent communication costs compared to FedAvg.
Even in the early stages (i.e., in restricted budget cases), FedDIP manages to match the communication efficiency of other pruning methods in the CIFAR experiments. This underscores the capacity of our approach to effectively balance model performance and communication expenditure. All in all, FedDIP introduces
only minor computational overhead due to the incremental regularization, while achieving high accuracy compared to baselines. This computational requirement is on par with that of PruneTrain, PruneFL, and SNIP, given the same sparsity at each epoch. A slight increase in computational cost can be justified by the improvements achieved in the final model performance considering extremely high sparsity. The size of the pruned CNN models (Table III) has been significantly reduced (∼similar-to\sim 1 order of magnitude) from the un-pruned models in FedAvg.

S6.T5.caption: Table V: Extension to non-i.i.d. data
S6.T5.table:
Model Performance1 (%percent\%) (non-i.i.d. case)
Case LeNet-5 AlexNet ResNet-18
FedAvg 76.42(0.28) 61.59 (0.73) 16.44 (0.49)
FedProx 76.63(0.34) 65.74 (0.26) 18.48 (0.91)
FedDIP+Prox 74.49 (0.09) 60.47 (0.52) 19.22 (0.8)
1 Mean of the highest five top-1 test accuracy during T𝑇T rounds.
references: As shown in Table V, our methodology exhibits strong adaptability to FedProx (non-pruning), yielding commendable results on non-i.i.d. data. When juxtaposed with FedAvg, our approach manages to maintain comparable results even after pruning 90%percent9090\% of model parameters, albeit at a slight trade-off of 1-2% in model accuracy in the experiments with LeNet-5 and AlexNet. Across a span of T=1000𝑇1000T=1000 rounds, FedDIP emerges as the superior performer in terms of top-1 accuracy, particularly at sparsity sp=0.8subscript𝑠𝑝0.8s_{p}=0.8 in ResNet-18. This comprehensive suite of results underscores the adaptability of FedDIP in effectively managing non-i.i.d. cases, even in extreme sparsity.
